title: Louisville president: No discussions about Rick Pitino resigning
text:
Louisville president: No discussions about Rick Pitino resigning Steve Jones, Courier-Journal 9:01 a.m. EDT October 22, 2015 James Ramsey said there have been no discussions about U of L basketball coach Rick Pitino resigning. (Courier-Journal) Buy Photo Louisville coach Rick Pitino is facing mounting criticism. (Photo: Mike Fender / The Star) Buy Photo CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
LOUISVILLE 
-- University of Louisville President James Ramsey said Wednesday that he has not talked with Rick Pitino about the possibility of the coach resigning over allegations that a former basketball staffer hired escorts to dance for and have sex with players and recruits in the team dormitory. 
After a meeting of the U of L Athletics Association's board of directors, Ramsey was asked about calls for Pitino to resign and if he's discussed that with the coach. "I don't know who's made those calls," Ramsey said, "but if they want to call me, they can do that." 
Ramsey, who spoke to reporters for less than two minutes, said he had not watched ESPN's "Outside The Lines" report in which Katina Powell, an escort who alleges in a book that she and other women were paid by former U of L staffer Andre McGee, spoke on camera for the first time. That report also cited five unnamed former Louisville players or recruits who described some details of stripper parties similar to those alleged in Powell's book, "Breaking Cardinal Rules: Basketball and the Escort Queen." 
"I didn't watch it. I didn't see it," Ramsey said. "There's an investigation taking place, and we're letting it play out, and I think that's the fair thing to do. 
"The investigation is taking place right now, and it is moving forward as a joint investigation of the university. It's representative Chuck Smrt, who we hired, and the NCAA, and it'll play out in a fair way and a way to find what the real truth is and what the real answers are. That's what we want, and that's what we expect."
